travels.title: France '10
travels.headertext: In May 2010, Jenny joined us for a fourteen day visit to France. We flew in to Lyons, then wandered west until we reached the Atlantic coast. We flew home from Bordeaux. _LEFT_BR_RIGHT_You'll find a day-by-day description _LEFT_a href=_Q_daybyday.php?destination=France10_Q__RIGHT_here._LEFT_/a_RIGHT_

entry.text: We started by flying to Lyons. Lyons started as the capital of Roman Gaul, so, yes, it has a lot of history. There are several Roman amphitheatres. We found Lyons as cosmopolitan as Paris, but with a more enjoyable scale (and without the Paris attitude). We walked many of the old, central neighborhoods near where the Rhone and Saone merge.

We picked up a car when we left Lyons, headed for the Auvergne. On the way, we went by Le Puy-en-Valey. Le Puy-en-Valey has several odd rock pillars that are the cinder cones of ancient volcanoes. They now have churches perched on them, making for some spectacular sights. We climbed up to one of the churches for great views of the city.

The Auvergne and Cantal are mountainous areas in central France. The peaks are only about 5000 feet high, but that's high enough to still have snow in May. The area is popular with skiers in the winter and hikers in the summer. Its a gorgeous natural area. We stayed in St. Nectaire and visited Le Mont Dore, La Bourboule, Orcival and other towns in the area. We also did short hikes in Le Mont Dore to Le Capucin and in the Vallee de Chaudefour. The picture is of the Roche Sanadoire. One thing we really liked about this area is that although its very popular with French tourists, it's off the tourist trail of most foreigners.

Next we traveled down to the Aveyron where we stayed in the small village of Belcastel. The place we stayed, Vieux Pont, has a one-star Michelin restaurant with it. We had dinner there one night. Amazing. While staying in Belcastel, we took a day trip to the Grotte du Pech-Merle, one of the caves with 30000 year old Cro-Magnon paintings, and the town of St. Cirq-Lapopie, perched on a hill side.

From the Aveyron, we moved west to the Dordogne Valley and the small town of Sergeac, located a little northeast of Sarlat-la-Caneda. The Dordogne valley is best know for the castels and chateaux that dot the region. It also has Cro-Magnon sites, Lascaux being the most famous, which we visited. Actually, like everyone else, we visited Lascaux II which is a reproduction of the real Lascaux which had to be closed to preserve it. From Sergeac, we also visited the town of Rocamadour (a pilgramige site and town carved into the hillside) and Gouffre de Padirac (a massive cave with a river flowing in it...it's so big, part of the visit is a boat ride in the cave). On the way there, we were also able to visit the zoo in Gramat that has a lot of European-specific animals you don't usually see elsewhere. We especially liked their wide collection of barnyard animals of all different types and breeds. In the Dordogne, we definitely rejoined the American and British tour trail.

St. Emillion is in wine country just east of Bordeaux. Its a pretty town, but strictly tourist, sort of the Disneyland of wine. We did take the tourist office tour of the underground church which was really interesting (even if it was in French). One of the oldest parts of St. Emillion is the "monolithic church", i.e. a church carved straight out of the limestone instead of being built stone by stone. The origins go back to the 8th century.

We stayed two night in St. Emillion. We spend the intervening day at the Atlantic coast. We visited Arcachon and then went to the Dune du Pilat, the largest sand dune in Europe. I wasn't expecting much from a sand dune, but it turned out to be fascinating. The thing is like 300 ft high, 1/4 mile wide and 2 miles long and growing every year. Its surrounded by a pine forest, planted on the orders of Napolean III to try to keep the dune from spreading. It towers over everything else and you can see for miles from the top. Its a very odd natural feature, but really, really interesting and fun to visit. With no further west to travel, we flew home from Bordeaux.
